modal-dialog.modal-heading: Who can claim the Child Tax Credit (CTC)?

modal-content.p: To claim the CTC, you must have a qualifying child who:

ul.li: Is your dependent child, stepchild, foster child, sibling, or descendant (grandchild, niece, nephew)
Is under 17 at the end of
Lives with you in the U.S. more than half the year
Has a Social Security number (SSN) valid for work (you or your spouse must also have an SSN)
Doesn’t support themselves or plans to file a joint return (unless to claim a refund)

modal-content.p: You can claim up to $ per qualifying child.

p.strong: How to check if you claimed this credit last year

modal-content.p: Review line 19 (CTC) and line 28 (Additional CTC) on Form 1040. If there’s a number other than zero on these lines, it means you’ve claimed the CTC, Additional CTC, or ODC before.

modal-dialog.modal-heading: Who can claim the Credit for Other Dependents (ODC)?

modal-content.p: To claim the ODC, you must have a qualifying dependent who:

ul.li: You plan to claim as a dependent on your tax return
Has a gross income less than $
Lives with you in the U.S. more than half the year if they’re a child or for all year if they’re an adult, unless they're a specific type of relative
Has a Social Security number, Individual Taxpayer Identification Number (ITIN), or Adoption Tax Identification Number (ATIN)
Doesn’t support themselves or plans to file a joint return
Won’t be used to claim the Child Tax Credit

modal-content.p: You can claim up to $ per qualifying dependent of any age.

p.strong: How to check if you claimed this credit last year

modal-content.p: Review line 19 (ODC). If there’s a number other than zero on these lines, it means you’ve claimed the ODC, CTC, or Additional CTC before.

modal-dialog.modal-heading: Who can claim the Child and Dependent Care Credit (CDCC) and what expenses are eligible?

modal-content.p: To claim the CDCC, you must be paying for the care of a child under 13 or for a spouse or dependent who lives with you and can’t care for themselves.
The person providing the care can’t be your spouse, the child’s parent, or another dependent.
Expenses that qualify:

ul.li: Daycare, preschool (below kindergarten)
Before- and after-school care
Day camps
Care for a spouse or dependent who can’t care for themselves

modal-content.p: Expenses that don’t qualify:

ul.li: Overnight camps
Private school tuition
Food, lodging, or clothing unless directly tied to care
Payments to your spouse, the child’s parent, or another dependent for care

modal-content.p: This is not a complete list. Refer to Publication 503 to learn more about which expenses qualify.
You can claim up to $ for one person or $ for two or more people.
If you’re married and filing separately from your spouse, you can only claim this credit if you and your spouse are legally separated or live apart and meet other criteria.

p.strong: How to check if you claimed this credit last year

modal-content.p: Review line 20 on Form 1040 of your federal tax return. Check for Form 2441 attached to Form 1040.

modal-dialog.modal-heading: Who can claim the Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC)?

modal-content.p: To claim the EITC with children, you must be a low- to moderate-income worker with a qualifying child.
A qualifying child for the EITC must:

ul.li: Be your child, stepchild, foster child, sibling, or descendant (grandchild, niece, nephew)
Be under 19 at the end of , under 24 at the end of if a full-time student, or any age if they are permanently disabled
Live with you in the U.S. more than half the year
Have a Social Security number valid for work
Not file a joint return (except to claim a refund)

modal-content.p: You can claim up to 3 qualifying children.
If you’re married and filing separately from your spouse, you can only claim this credit if you meet specific criteria.
To claim the EITC without children, you must be a low- to moderate-income worker who:

ul.li: Will be 25 to 64 years old on January 1,
Lived in the U.S. for more than half the year
Have a Social Security number valid for work

p.strong: How to check if you claimed this credit last year

modal-content.p: Review line 27a on Form 1040 of your federal tax return.

modal-dialog.modal-heading: Who can claim the Retirement Savings Credit?

modal-content.p: To claim the Retirement Savings Credit, you must contribute to a traditional IRA, Roth IRA, 401(k), 403(b), or similar plan.
These contributions don’t qualify:

ul.li: Employer contributions or matches
Rollover contributions

modal-content.p: You can claim up to $ for yourself, and $ for your spouse (if filing jointly).

p.strong: How to check if you claimed this credit last year

modal-content.p: Review line 20 of your Form 1040 of your federal tax return, and line 4 of Schedule 3.

p.a: Learn more about the Retirement Savings Credit.

modal-dialog.modal-heading: Who can claim the American Opportunity Tax Credit (AOTC) and what expenses qualify?

modal-content.p: To claim the AOTC, you, your spouse, or a dependent must:

ul.li: Be in the first 4 years of higher education
Enroll at least half-time to pursue a degree or credential

modal-content.p: You can claim up to $ per student, including:

ul.li: 100% of the first $2,000 in expenses
25% of the next $2,000 in expenses

modal-content.p: Expenses can include tuition, fees, books, supplies, and other items. You can claim expenses paid by you, your spouse, your dependent, or a third party.
This credit can’t be claimed more than 4 times per student.
You can’t claim both the American Opportunity Tax Credit and the Lifetime Learning Credit for the same student.

p.strong: How to check if you claimed this credit last year

modal-content.p: Review line 20 (nonrefundable) and line 29 (refundable) of your Form 1040 federal tax return. Check for Form 8863 attached to Form 1040.

modal-dialog.modal-heading: Who can claim the Lifetime Learning Credit?

modal-content.p: To claim the Lifetime Learning Credit, you, your spouse, or a dependent must:

ul.li: Pay tuition or fees for college courses, professional certifications, or job skill trainings
Enroll or take courses at an eligible educational institution
Enroll in one or more courses for an academic period in

modal-content.p: You can claim up to 20% of the first $10,000 in expenses and a maximum of $ per federal tax return. You may claim expenses paid by you, your spouse, your dependent, or a third party.
You can’t claim both the American Opportunity Tax Credit and the Lifetime Learning Credit for the same student.

p.strong: How to check if you claimed this credit last year

modal-content.p: Review line 20 of your Form 1040 federal tax return. Check for Form 8863, Part II, which would’ve been attached and submitted with the federal tax return.

p.a: Learn more about the Lifetime Learning Credit.

modal-dialog.modal-heading: Who can claim the Adoption Credit?

modal-content.p: To claim the Adoption Credit, you or your spouse must:

ul.li: Have paid qualified adoption expenses such as adoption fees, court costs, attorney fees, or travel
Adopt a child under 18, or who is physically or mentally unable to care for themselves

modal-content.p: You can claim up to $ in qualified expenses per adopted child. When to claim expenses depends on adoption type, adoption status, and when expenses were incurred.
This credit is partially refundable. It can reduce your taxes and give you a refund up to $ if it brings your tax owed to $0. Unused amounts can be carried forward for up to 5 years.
If you’re married and filing separately from your spouse, you can only claim this credit if you lived apart from your spouse and meet other criteria.

p.strong: How to check if you claimed this credit last year

modal-content.p: Review Form 8839 (Qualified Adoption Expenses) if attached to prior year Form 1040.

p.a: Learn more about the Adoption Credit.

modal-dialog.modal-heading: Who can claim the elderly or disabled credit?

modal-content.p: You may qualify if your income is below IRS limits and:

ul.li: You are 65 years old or older on January 1, , or
You retire on permanent and total disability and receive taxable disability income

modal-content.p: We’ll estimate this credit based on your age, income, and filing status.
If you're filing as married filing separately, you can only claim this credit if you meet specific criteria.
If you're filing as head of household, you can only claim this credit if you meet specific criteria.

p.strong: How to check if you claimed this credit last year

modal-content.p: Review Schedule R (Credit for the Elderly or Disabled) attached to Form 1040.

p.a: Learn more about the Elderly or Disabled Credit.

modal-dialog.modal-heading: Who can claim the foreign tax credit?

modal-content.p: To claim the foreign tax credit, you or your spouse must:

ul.li: Pay or owe taxes to a foreign country or U.S. territory, and
Be subject to U.S. tax on the same income

modal-content.p: If you're planning to take an itemized deduction for foreign tax, then you won't be able to claim this credit.

p.strong: How to check if you claimed this credit last year

modal-content.p: Review Form 1040, Schedule 3, line 1. Check if Form 1116 was attached.

p.a: Learn more about the Foreign Tax Credit.

modal-content.p: Business credits are a group of tax credits that include incentives for activities such as:

ul.li: Hiring and supporting workers
Energy investments
Research and development

modal-content.p: You may need to file Form 3800 to claim them.

p.strong: How to check if you claimed this credit last year

modal-content.p: Review Form 3800, General Business Credit, attached to Form 1040.

p.a: Learn more about business tax credits.

modal-dialog.modal-heading: Who can claim the mortgage interest credit?

modal-content.p: To claim the mortgage interest credit, you and your spouse must:

ul.li: Have a qualified Mortgage Credit Certificate (MCC) from your state or local government
Pay mortgage interest on your main home

modal-content.p: The MCC will show the percentage of interest you can claim as a credit. If you don’t have an MCC, you can’t claim this credit.
This credit is limited to $2,000 per year.

p.strong: How to check if you claimed this credit last year

modal-content.p: Review Form 8396 attached to Form 1040.

p.a: Learn more about the Mortgage Interest Credit.

modal-dialog.modal-heading: Who can claim the Alternative Minimum Tax (AMT) Credit?

modal-content.p: To claim the AMT, you or your spouse must:

ul.li: Have owed AMT in a prior year
Not be subject to AMT in the current year

modal-content.p: You can claim this credit by filing Form 8801.

p.strong: How to check if you claimed this credit last year

modal-content.p: Review Form 8801, Credit for Prior Year Minimum Tax.
